awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Synthesis, Characterization, and Modeling of Complex Amorphous Semiconductors for Future Device Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: By understanding a material's structure, it is possible to predict and design its properties. Whereas crystals are well-understood by their regular pattern of atoms, the structure of amorphous materials with their randomly bonded atoms is extremely challenging to determine. Yet this disorganized structure is exactly what makes these materials advantageous for many technological applications. For example, large-areas can be coated with amorphous materials in smooth layers for application in the next-generation flexible flat panel displays. An important objective of this project is to gather, decipher, integrate, and organize large experimental and computer generated data to accurately describe the structure and properties of a large class of complex amorphous materials. This materials data along with open-source statistical software developed within the project will be made accessible as part of the Global Materials Network to accelerate the discovery of new materials with unique features and performance and to help produce new products at a much faster pace and reduced cost. 
 
Technical Description: Unlike Si-based semiconductors, amorphous oxide semiconductors exhibit optical, electrical, thermal, and mechanical properties that are comparable or even superior to those possessed by their crystalline counterparts. Most notably, carrier mobility of amorphous oxide semiconductors is an order of magnitude larger than that of amorphous hydrogenated silicon commonly used in solar cells and flat-panel displays. Within unified theoretical and experimental framework, this project aims to establish genomic deposition-structure-property relationships in complex amorphous oxide and chalcogenide semiconductors in order to systematically record and organize the data into a searchable database. The research will integrate controlled synthesis, advanced characterization, multi-scale modeling, time-dependent studies, and accurate first-principles calculations to provide microscopic understanding of the complex interplay between the nanostructure, morphology, and electron transport regimes across the entire crystalline-to-amorphous transition. Development of realistic approaches for non-stoichiometric-melt cooling and time-dependent statistical analysis, will enable studies of defect formation and dynamics, ion diffusion, structural evolution and stretched-exponential relaxation, phase transformation, and crystallization processes, bringing the computer-aided design of amorphous materials to a new level. The PIs plan to release the Amorphous Structure Analysis (AStA) as open source and build a user community around the language by ensuring that interested researchers are able to contribute to AStA codebase. This will allow a wider growth of the project. This aspect is of special interest to the software cluster in the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure, which has provided co-funding for this award.

por.por_cntn:
Summary: The project goal was three-fold: (1) to gather, decipher, validate, integrate, organize, and disseminate large computer-generated data that accurately describes the structure and properties of binary, ternary, and quaternary amorphous oxide semiconductor (AOS) materials; (2) to establish the role and interdependence of relevant growth parameters and (post)deposition conditions in the resulting structural, electronic, transport, and optical properties of the disordered oxides; and (3) to make the materials data, standardized characterization methods, and opensource statistical software accessible and useful to the community. Intellectual Merit: Genomic deposition-structure-property relationships were established for families of AOS with variable density, stoichiometry, morphology, cation and/or anion composition, and hydrogenation using high-throughput computational simulations seamlessly integrated with the results of systematic experimental synthesis, including precision pulsed laser deposition (PLD) by R.P.H. Chang, solution processing by T. Marks and A. Facchetti, PLD and sputtering by M. Bertoni, and validated using comprehensive characterization of the short- and medium-range structure (in collaboration with V. Dravid, M. Bedzyk, M. Bertoni) and property measurements (M. Grayson, A. Facchetti, M. Bertoni). Using our developed approach for non-stoichiometric-melt cooling, the fundamental principles of defect formation and the structural, electronic, and dynamic characteristics of defects in ionic AOS are formulated, highlighting the striking differences from point defects in the crystalline counterparts. Data and DMREF Specific Criteria: The results of computationallyintensive ab-initio molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and electronic property calculations using a hybrid functional are tabulated and organized for multi-parameter database that includes amorphous In2Ox, Ga2Ox, SnOx, ZnOx, (In1-y,Gay)2Ox, (In,Sn)yOx, In2(O1-x,Fx)3, In2(O1-x,Sx)3, (Zn1-ySny)Ox, Zn0.15In0.70Sn0.15Ox, (In1?y?z,Ga1?y,Zn1?z)Ox, MoO3, Al2O3, B2O3, (Al,B)2O3, ZrO2, Zr(O1-x,Fx)2, SrTiO3-x. A comprehensive time-dependent statistical analysis tool to describe structure, morphology, and dynamics in disordered materials is developed as an open-source software. A new transient measurement technique, the frequency-multiplexed Hall effect method, is developed in order to measure the transient Hall effect simultaneously with the transient sheet resistance, thereby separating the mobility transient from the electron density transient. Broader Impacts: A high-quality ?heteromorphic? superlattice comprised of repeated layers of semiconducting polycrystalline In2O3 layers interleaved with insulating amorphous MoO3 layers was realized, validating the idea that bond angle flexibility, preservation of stoichiometry, and the resulting passivation at the crystalline-amorphous interfacial region creates smooth, high-mobility interfaces. The HSL with a 7:7 nm layer thickness exhibits an electron mobility observed in the highest quality In2O3 thin films. Three distinct phase-coherent tunneling transport regimes were observed. The weak-localization signatures prove that these interfaces are sufficiently defect-free for electrons to coherently tunnel through multiple layers. Education and outreach: New upperundergraduate course ?Computational Lab? is developed using MGI paradigm. New workshop ?From Cookies to Computers? is developed for Expanding Your Horizon program for 7-8th grade girls from rural Missouri. Several science/theater outreach events, both virtual and in-person, were conducted at Northwestern. 4 postdocs, 6 graduate and 9 undergraduate students trained. Products: 16 papers, 2 book chapters, 1 Ph.D. Thesis, and 1 patent have been published, accepted, or submitted; 13 manuscripts and 1 patent are in (final) preparation.
